section.name: DB Security Service
section.p: This is an implementation of a Security Service which uses Torque generated peers to access the required security information.

Older versions of the Security Service used hard coded Peers to access the security information. The current version can access arbitrary peers to retrieve the information and can be adapted to a pre-existing schema and use peer classes from outside Fulcrum.

section.name: Using the supplied Peer classes
section.p:
When you start with the Security Service, you should use the Fulcrum supplied Peer classes to familiarize yourself with the workings of the DB Security Service. Once you understand how the peer classes are accessed, you can customize to your own Peer classes. Fulcrum supplies the following peer classes and objects to retrieve data:
Object type Function Class
User Implementation org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.DBUser
Peer org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.entity.TurbineUserPeer
Persistent object org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.entity.TurbineUser
Group Implementation org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.DBGroup
Peer org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.entity.TurbineGroupPeer
Persistent object org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.entity.TurbineGroup
Role Implementation org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.DBRole
Peer org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.entity.TurbineRolePeer
Persistent object org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.entity.TurbineRole
Permission Implementation org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.DBPermission
Peer org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.entity.TurbinePermissionPeer
Persistent object org.apache.fulcrum.impl.db.entity.TurbinePermission
If you retrieve objects from the DB Security Service, you will always get the object classes in the "Implementation" rows. The DB Security Service will use the peers described in the "Peer" rows and internally the implementation objects will use the objects from the "Persistent" rows. As you will see later, you can reconfigure the "Peer" and "Persistent" objects.

section.name: Fulcrum supplied table schema
section.p: The Peers and objects supplied with the DB Security Service were generated from a Torque Schema. Its definition is shown here.
Fulcrum uses the following configuration for accessing the Torque schema. If you just want to use the default Peers, you don't need any of the following configuration, these are the defaults:
section.source:
# This is the Peer class used to access the user peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineUserPeer) services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.class = org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineUserPeer
# The columns in the peer used to retrieve information. These are the names of the constants # in the configured peer services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.name = LOGIN_NAME services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.id = USER_ID services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.password = PASSWORD_VALUE services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.firstname = FIRST_NAME services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.lastname = LAST_NAME services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.email = EMAIL services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.confirm = CONFIRM_VALUE services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.createdate = CREATED services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.lastlogin = LAST_LOGIN services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.column.objectdata = OBJECTDATA
# These are the objects returned by the configured user peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineUser) services.SecurityService.db.user.class = org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineUser
# These bean properties are queried from the returned object to retrieve the # information services.SecurityService.db.user.property.name = UserName services.SecurityService.db.user.property.id = UserId services.SecurityService.db.user.property.password = Password services.SecurityService.db.user.property.firstname = FirstName services.SecurityService.db.user.property.lastname = LastName services.SecurityService.db.user.property.email = Email services.SecurityService.db.user.property.confirm = Confirmed services.SecurityService.db.user.property.createdate = CreateDate services.SecurityService.db.user.property.lastlogin = LastLogin services.SecurityService.db.user.property.objectdata = Objectdata
# This is the Peer class used to access the Group Peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineGroupPeer) services.SecurityService.db.groupPeer.class = org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineGroupPeer
# The columns in the peer used to retrieve information. These are the names of the constants # in the configured peer services.SecurityService.db.groupPeer.column.name = GROUP_NAME services.SecurityService.db.groupPeer.column.id = GROUP_ID
# These are the objects returned by the configured group peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineGroup) services.SecurityService.db.group.class = org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineGroup
# These bean properties are queried from the returned object to retrieve the # information services.SecurityService.db.group.property.name = Name services.SecurityService.db.group.property.id = GroupId
# This is the Peer class used to access the Role Peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineRolePeer) services.SecurityService.db.rolePeer.class = org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineRolePeer
# The columns in the peer used to retrieve information. These are the names of the constants # in the configured peer services.SecurityService.db.rolePeer.column.name = ROLE_NAME services.SecurityService.db.rolePeer.column.id = ROLE_ID
# These are the objects returned by the configured role peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineRole) services.SecurityService.db.role.class = org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineRole
# These bean properties are queried from the returned object to retrieve the # information services.SecurityService.db.role.property.name = Name services.SecurityService.db.role.property.id = RoleId
# This is the Peer class used to access the Permission Peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbinePermissionPeer) services.SecurityService.db.permissionPeer.class = org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbinePermissionPeer
# The columns in the peer used to retrieve information. These are the names of the constants # in the configured peer services.SecurityService.db.permissionPeer.column.name = PERMISSION_NAME services.SecurityService.db.permissionPeer.column.id = PERMISSION_ID
# These are the objects returned by the configured permission peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbinePermission) services.SecurityService.db.permission.class = org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbinePermission
# These bean properties are queried from the returned object to retrieve the # information services.SecurityService.db.permission.property.name = Name services.SecurityService.db.permission.property.id = PermissionId
section.p: The column names and the bean properties do not always match, because you can change the name of the bean property with the javaName attribute in the Torque XML file.

If you omit the class definition of the object classes (db.user.class, db.group.class, db.role.class, db.permission.class), the bean property OMClass in the peer is consulted which should return the default class that this peer returns.

section.name: Configuring DB Security Service to use your own peer classes
section.p: The most interesting application for this is to extend some of the tables with more columns for additional data. In this example, the User table gets extended by two more columns called "TELEPHONE" and "FAX".
At first we create a new torque schema:
section.source:
<table name="CUSTOM_USER" idMethod="idbroker"> <column name="USER_ID" required="true" primaryKey="true" type="INTEGER"/> <column name="LOGIN_NAME" required="true" size="64" type="VARCHAR" javaName="UserName"/> <column name="PASSWORD_VALUE" required="true" size="16" type="VARCHAR" javaName="Password"/> <column name="FIRST_NAME" required="true" size="64" type="VARCHAR"/> <column name="LAST_NAME" required="true" size="64" type="VARCHAR"/> <column name="EMAIL" size="64" type="VARCHAR"/> <column name="CONFIRM_VALUE" size="16" type="VARCHAR" javaName="Confirmed"/> <column name="MODIFIED" type="TIMESTAMP"/> <column name="CREATED" type="TIMESTAMP" javaName="CreateDate"/> <column name="LAST_LOGIN" type="TIMESTAMP"/> <column name="OBJECTDATA" type="VARBINARY"/>
<column name="TELEPHONE" size="32" type="VARCHAR" javaName="Phone" /> <column name="FAX" size="32" type="VARCHAR"/>
<unique> <unique-column name="LOGIN_NAME"/> </unique>
section.p:
Note a few things:
This schema is the same as the TURBINE_USER schema from Fulcrum with the addition of two columns. This is especially important with regard to the "javaName" attributes which configure the name of the property for this column in the persistent objects.
The "TELEPHONE" column has its property name set to "Phone".
The Torque schema now gets translated into two java classes: CustomUserPeer for accessing the tables and CustomUser as objects returned by the Peer.
Now we configure the DB Security Service to for using this peer as UserPeer:
section.source: # This is the Peer class used to access the user peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineUserPeer) services.SecurityService.db.userPeer.class = CustomUserPeer
section.p: Please note that we neither configure any column or property properties nor do we configure services.SecurityService.db.user.class. So the DB Security Service will query the CustomPeer for the class of the returned objects. Now Fulcrum uses your supplied Custom User Peer for querying User information. However you can't access your custom columns (yet)...

section.name: Advanced customization
section.p: Consider the following schema:
If you want to use this as the role peer, you can configure the DB Security Service like this:
section.source:
services.SecurityService.db.rolePeer.class = CustomRolePeer
# The columns in the peer used to retrieve information. These are the names of the constants # in the configured peer services.SecurityService.db.rolePeer.column.name = NAME_OF_ROLE services.SecurityService.db.rolePeer.column.id = CUSTOM_ID
# These are the objects returned by the configured role peer (org.apache.fulcrum.security.impl.db.entity.TurbineRole) services.SecurityService.db.role.class = CustomRole
# These bean properties are queried from the returned object to retrieve the # information services.SecurityService.db.role.property.name = NameOfRole services.SecurityService.db.role.property.id = CustomId
section.p: Of course you must assure that the necessary foreign key relations in the database are still valid. With some databases, e.g. MySQL this is not a big concern, because they don't support foreign keys at all.
